Situation1: The weekly group meditation meets for an hour today.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I sit cross-legged on the cushion, the familiar hush of the meditation hall settling around me. As a Buddhist, I cherish these weekly group meditations—an hour to practice mindfulness, to let go of the world’s noise. But today, my mind refuses to quiet. My phone buzzes in my bag, a reminder that my volunteer shift at the community kitchen starts in twenty minutes. I know the others can cover for a while if I’m late, but I also know the expectation: show up on time, be reliable. I promised them, just as I promised myself to be present here. My teacher’s voice floats through the silence, urging us to focus on our breath, but my thoughts tug me toward the kitchen, to the faces waiting for a hot meal. I feel torn—my heart aches to honor both commitments, but the demands pull me in opposite directions. I close my eyes, wrestling with the weight of these roles, uncertain which path to choose.
